Approach and Solution\\\\n  \\\\n\\\\n### Primary Approach and Solution\\\\n\\\\nLiquify will utilise a three-pronged strategy to address NEAR\\\\\\'s RPC infrastructure needs:\\\\n\\\\n1. This approach ensures that NEAR developers can access both centralised and decentralised RPC services, empowering them with the flexibility to choose the best infrastructure for their specific use case.\\\\n\\\\n### Why Choose Liquify\\\\n\\\\nLiquify is uniquely positioned to accelerate NEAR\\\\\\'s developer experience by offering a balanced solution that addresses both centralised and decentralised needs. Liquify\\\\\\'s platform offers a variety of RPC experiences to cater to the diverse requirements of different projects and developers within the NEAR ecosystem.\\\\n  \\\\nWith proven experience and a long-standing relationship with NEAR, Liquify can ensure a seamless transition from NEAR\\\\\\'s current RPC setup while introducing improvements in performance, decentralisation, and flexibility. This combination makes Liquify the optimal partner to lead NEAR\\\\\\'s infrastructure into the future.\\\\n  \\\\n**Open Source and Licensing**\\\\nAll software developed as part of this project will be released under Apache 2.0 or MIT licences, fostering community collaboration and transparency.\\\\n\\\\n  \\\\n# 6. Multi-Gateway Decentralisation\\\\n\\\\nWith Liquify providing the foundational infrastructure layer for decentralised RPC protocols, NEAR can be widely supported on numerous gateways. This would be the first time NEAR would have full support, including archival, on these protocols.\\\\n\\\\nBy enabling NEAR on these RPC protocols, NEAR developers will have multiple gateway options, providing unique UXs, payment methods, and pricing structures. Goals / Milestones\\\\n\\\\n**Goal 1: Transition Planning and Knowledge Transfer**  \\\\n*Completion by November 1, 2024*\\\\n\\\\n- Conduct workshops with Pagoda and NEAR teams to outline the transition strategy.\\\\n- Develop a comprehensive knowledge transfer document detailing the current infrastructure setup.\\\\n- Help test with the community focused on snapshot repair\\\\n\\\\n**Goal 2: Infrastructure Deployment**  \\\\n*Completion by December 1, 2024*\\\\n\\\\n- Deploy Liquify\\\\\\'s infrastructure for NEAR mainnet and testnet RPC services.\\\\n- Begin deployment of NEAR Archival across the globe in collaboration with the community focused on snapshot repair.\\\\n- Implement rate-limited free-tier services for developers.\\\\n- Share initial performance report.\\\\n- Fully support NEAR on supported decentralised infrastructure protocols\\\\n\\\\n**Goal 3: Performance Optimization and SLA Implementation**  \\\\n*Completion by February 1, 2024*\\\\n\\\\n- Launch Liquify\\\\\\'s NEAR portal\\\\n- Optimise infrastructure performance and implement the SLA.\\\\n- Establish external status pages and alerting systems for real-time monitoring.\\\\n\\\\n**Goal 4: Community Engagement + Enchanced Decentralization**  \\\\n*Completion by March 1, 2025*\\\\n\\\\n- Engage the developer community through workshops and/or webinars.\\\\n- Advocate for increased NEAR exposure on existing and future decentralised infrastructure protocols\\\\n\\\\n# 8. Metrics\\\\n\\\\n**Key Metrics for Success**\\\\n\\\\n- Uptime and Performance: Achieving 99.95% uptime and sub-200ms response time for mainnet RPC.\\\\n- User Adoption: Number of developers and dApps using the Liquify RPC portal, and seeing NEAR continually supported on decentralised protocols LAVA, POKT and possibly others.\\\\n- Community Engagement: Participation in workshops and feedback from NEAR developers.\\\\n\\\\n**Measurement Plan**\\\\n\\\\n- Continuous monitoring through Liquify\\\\\\'s dashboard and other protocols.\\\\n- Monthly reports to the NEAR Foundation on SLA compliance, user adoption, and community feedback.\\\\n\\\\n# 9. Competitor Comparison\\\\n\\\\n**Competitor Analysis**\\\\n  \\\\n- **Standard Providers:** Most RPC services rely on the cloud or hardware rental services for their infrastructure, making deployment significantly more challenging when trying to establish world coverage. These providers are subject to changing rental costs, hardware availability, usage agreements, etc. Liquify is unique in it owns all of their hardware, ensuring complete global coverage of our services.\\\\n- **Decentralised Providers:** While they align with the ethos of decentralisation, they often struggle with performance and reliability issues due to fragmented infrastructure.\\\\n\\\\n**Unique Value Proposition**  \\\\nLiquify bridges the gap between these two models, providing a hybrid solution that combines the high performance and reliability of centralised infrastructure with the resilience and decentralisation of protocols. This makes us uniquely capable of supporting NEAR\\\\\\'s needs as it transitions to a more decentralised future.\\\\n\\\\n  \\\\n# 10. Usage & Examples\\\\n\\\\n**Current Users**\\\\n\\\\n- Infura: Liquify serves as the primary backup infrastructure to Infura, serving the lion share of all requests going through [DIN](https://www.infura.io/solutions/decentralized-infrastructure-service) due to our response times and reliability.\\\\n- Defi Kingdoms: Liquify\\\\\\'s infrastructure successfully managed over 1 billion RPC requests a day with minimal latency and a 99.9999% success rate.\\\\n- TRGC: Supported their portfolio companies with efficient, cost-effective infrastructure solutions, demonstrating our ability to handle mission-critical systems.\\\\n\\\\n**Potential Use Cases**\\\\n\\\\n- NEAR developers that require stable and high-performance RPC access, with a user experience similar to other ecosystems.\\\\n- dApps wanting a true decentralised experience through decentralised RPC protocols, knowing that Liquify is providing a reliable, fast, core infrastructure.\\\\n\\\\n**Scalability Examples**  \\\\nLiquify has demonstrated the ability to scale infrastructure to handle up to 200,000 requests per minute, far exceeding NEAR\\\\\\'s current traffic requirements. We have consistently delivered high-quality, high-performance RPC services, supporting 60+ chains, including NEAR, to customers directly or through decentralised RPC protocols. This scalability will support NEAR\\\\\\'s growth and ensure reliable service for developers and users.\\\\n\\\\n  \\\\n# 11. This proposal outlines a phased approach to integrate NEAR\\\\u{2019}s blockchain data into KYVE\\\\u{2019}s Web3 data lake, enabling validated and permanently stored data streams for developers, analysts, and businesses within the NEAR ecosystem.", "category": "Infrastructure Committee", "timeline": {"status": "REJECTED", "sponsor_requested_review": false, "reviewer_completed_attestation": false}, "linked_rfp": 3, "supervisor": "trechriron71.near", "description": "# NEAR Data Integration into KYVE\\\\u{2019}s Decentralized Data Lake\\\\n\\\\n**Description:**\\\\n\\\\nThis is a combined proposal for the following RFPs: [NEAR Lake](https://dev.near.org/infrastructure-committee.near/widget/app?page=rfp&id=3), [BigQuery, and Data Pipelines](https://dev.near.org/infrastructure-committee.near/widget/app?page=rfp&id=4). It also includes a **Trustless** **API** to query NEAR historical data, with the long-term vision of decentralizing the NEAR data infrastructure and turning NEAR data into a public good.\\\\n\\\\n## **Project Abstract**\\\\n\\\\nAs NEAR\\\\u{2019}s data infrastructure undergoes significant changes with Pagoda winding down, there is a **growing need for decentralized and validated data solutions** to ensure secure and scalable access to NEAR\\\\u{2019}s blockchain data. This proposal outlines a phased approach to integrate NEAR\\\\u{2019}s blockchain data into KYVE\\\\u{2019}s Web3 data lake, enabling validated and permanently stored data streams for developers, analysts, and businesses within the NEAR ecosystem.\\\\n\\\\n**What is KYVE?**\\\\n\\\\nKYVE, a data validation and transfer protocol,  enables data providers to standardize, validate, and permanently store data streams. It leverages permanent data storage solutions like Arweave and uses its own Layer-1 Blockchain, ensuring the scalability, immutability, and availability of archived data over time.\\\\n\\\\nKYVE\\\\\\'s Network is powered by decentralized validators, which are rewarded in $KYVE and other tokens ([https://docs.kyve.network/](https://docs.kyve.network/)).\\\\n\\\\n## **Objectives**\\\\n\\\\nThe goal of this integration is to create a robust and sustainable data infrastructure for the NEAR ecosystem. Unlike centralized solutions, KYVE relies on a network of decentralized providers to store, validate, and serve blockchain data. This reduces the risk of single points of failure and removes dependencies on centralized services.\\\\n\\\\nThe integration of NEAR\\\\u{2019}s blockchain data into KYVE\\\\\\'s decentralized data lake ensures long-term availability, immutability, and verifiability. By utilizing decentralized storage providers like Arweave, NEAR data becomes a public good, eliminating the need for centralized services and reducing risks. KYVE\\\\u{2019}s built-in tools, including the Trustless API and Data Load Tool, provide seamless access to validated data, future-proofing NEAR\\\\u{2019}s data infrastructure.\\\\n\\\\n## **Outcomes**\\\\n\\\\nThe integration of NEAR\\\\u{2019}s blockchain data into KYVE\\\\u{2019}s decentralized data lake will deliver significant benefits across three major products: KYVE Data Lake, Data Load Tool, and Trustless API.\\\\n\\\\n**1. KYVE\\\\u{2019}s Decentralized Data Lake ([https://app.kyve.network/#/sources](https://app.kyve.network/#/sources))**\\\\n\\\\nNEAR\\\\u{2019}s blockchain data is validated by KYVE and stored on Arweave, ensuring permanent, decentralized storage. Validators are rewarded in $NEAR for maintaining data accuracy, reducing reliance on centralized services and securing the long-term availability of NEAR data as a public good.\\\\n\\\\n**2. Data Load Tool Support ([https://docs.kyve.network/access-data-sets/data-pipeline/overview](https://docs.kyve.network/access-data-sets/data-pipeline/overview))**\\\\n\\\\nKYVE\\\\u{2019}s Data Load Tool streamlines transferring NEAR blockchain data to external warehouses like BigQuery and Postgres, removing the need for custom pipelines. With Load and Sync commands, data is kept fresh and accessible for analysis. Additional steps enable full schematization for deeper insights.\\\\n\\\\n**3. Trustless API ([https://docs.kyve.network/access-data-sets/trustless-api/overview](https://docs.kyve.network/access-data-sets/trustless-api/overview))**\\\\n\\\\nKYVE\\\\u{2019}s Trustless API offers verifiable, decentralized access to historical and live NEAR data (2-minute latency), secured by Merkle Proofs. Developers can easily integrate data into applications via well-known endpoints. The open-source tool enables independent deployment for scalability without stressing node infrastructure.\\\\n\\\\n## **Project Team**\\\\n\\\\n*This is a joint proposal by KYVE Foundation & BCP Innovations, combining deep expertise in decentralized data infrastructure with a strong commitment to driving innovation in Web3 technologies. Together, we are committed to creating a secure, decentralized, and robust data ecosystem for the NEAR blockchain through KYVE\\\\u{2019}s cutting-edge solutions.*\\\\n\\\\n**KYVE Foundation**\\\\n\\\\nThe KYVE Foundation supports the development and growth of KYVE\\\\u{2019}s decentralized data infrastructure, with a strong emphasis on decentralization, security, and data integrity. Backed by key industry players, KYVE ensures secure and scalable data solutions for leading blockchain ecosystems like Cosmos Hub, Celestia, Archway, dYdX, and others.\\\\n\\\\n**BCP Innovations**\\\\n\\\\nBCP Innovations is a German Web3 development company specializing in blockchain infrastructure and decentralized applications. As the team behind KYVE, BCP Innovations delivers secure data validation and permanent storage. For the NEAR-KYVE integration, BCP will build secure data pipelines to ensure NEAR\\\\\\'s blockchain data remains available and immutable.\\\\n\\\\n**Project Team:**\\\\n\\\\n**Fabian Riewe: BCP CEO and KYVE Founder,**- ([https://github.com/fabianriewe](https://github.com/fabianriewe)) - [fabian@kyve.network](mailto:fabian@kyve.network)\\\\n\\\\n**Maximilian Breithecker:** Data Engineer and Blockchain Developer,  ([https://github.com/mbreithecker](https://github.com/mbreithecker)) - [max@kyve.network](mailto:max@kyve.network)\\\\n\\\\n**Troy Kessler:** Protocol Developer,  [https://github.com/troykessler](https://github.com/troykessler) - troy@kyve.network\\\\n\\\\n**Christopher Brumm:** Developer [https://github.com/christopherbrumm](https://github.com/christopherbrumm) - [christopher@kyve.network](mailto:christopher@kyve.network)\\\\n\\\\nFor more details on BCP contributions, please see the Github repositories. All tools from this integration will be released under an **Open Source license**, ensuring transparency, community collaboration, and wide adoption.\\\\n\\\\n- [https://github.com/KYVENetwork/chain](https://github.com/KYVENetwork/chain)\\\\n- [https://github.com/KYVENetwork/kyvejs](https://github.com/KYVENetwork/kyvejs)\\\\n- https://github.com/KYVENetwork/kyve-dlt\\\\n- [https://github.com/KYVENetwork/trustless-api](https://github.com/KYVENetwork/trustless-api)\\\\n- [https://github.com/KYVENetwork/ksync](https://github.com/KYVENetwork/ksync)\\\\n- [https://docs.kyve.network/](https://docs.kyve.network/)\\\\n\\\\n## **Usage & Examples**\\\\n\\\\n**Current Users of KYVE\\\\\\'s Decentralized Data Lake**\\\\n\\\\n**KYVE** serves as the trusted data infrastructure for leading blockchain ecosystems like **Celestia, Osmosis, dYdX**, and **more**  ensuring their on-chain data is securely validated and permanently stored through decentralized storage solutions like **Arweave**. These projects use KYVE to maintain the integrity, accessibility, and reliability of their mission-critical blockchain data without needing to manage complex, centralized infrastructure. By using KYVE, they benefit from decentralized validation and long-term storage, ensuring data remains immutable and available for future use as a public good. [https://app.kyve.network/#/sources](https://app.kyve.network/#/sources)\\\\n\\\\n**Statistics:**\\\\n\\\\n- **+70M Transactions**\\\\n- **+7,87 TB validated and archived on Arweave (Mainnet)**\\\\n- **+18.54 TB validated and archived on Testnet**\\\\n\\\\nKYVE continues to scale its infrastructure, making it a cornerstone for secure and scalable data management in Web3 ecosystems.\\\\n\\\\n**Google BigQuery Data Sets:**\\\\n\\\\nLeveraging KYVE\\\\u{2019}s data load pipeline, BCP Innovations has published several datasets, such as those for **Osmosis**, **dYdX, Celestia, Noble** making it significantly easier for developers and data analysts to access and use blockchain data without needing to sync it from scratch. This eliminates the time-consuming process of syncing large amounts of historical data, allowing users to quickly query and analyze data. This ensures a consistent, secure, and reliable infrastructure for applications.\\\\n\\\\ndApps and Blockchain Analytics: Decentralized applications and analytics platforms can rely on KYVE to validate and archive NEAR data in a fully decentralized way, ensuring data integrity and reducing reliance on centralized systems, while enabling in-depth analysis and insights.\\\\n\\\\n**Proof of Concept: NEAR Trustless API Demo:**\\\\n\\\\nThe **Trustless API** enables developers to seamlessly connect their applications and dApps to verified blockchain data. Our decentralized approach will prepare NEAR Lake for upcoming challenges like dynamic sharding, while supporting the current NEAR Lake libraries. With a proven track record of reliability, Lava is ready to handle the increasing complexity and growing demands of NEAR Lake\\\\u{2019}s infrastructure, as well as improve its access as a public good by exposing it to developers to query.\\\\n\\\\nNear lake\\\\u{2019}s integration will allow the enhancement of APIs on near, seamless replacement of vendors, and competition over performance and price, with the goal of replacing the need for RPFs in the future and allowing vendors to compete based on queries and costs.\\\\n\\\\n**This approach allows near to transition from a single provider, and a risk factor that needs to be addressed regularly by the infrastructure committee into an automatic technically solved solution that can scale and allow competitiveness.** \\\\n\\\\nVendors will be encouraged to improve their costs and will allow the flexibility of any solution to be integrated in the future. We aim for the transition to be gradual, focusing on stability and making steps towards the goal of decentralizing and monetising the solution based on usage, while still offering the base rates as a public good.\\\\n\\\\n## Technical Requirements and Solution Proposal\\\\n\\\\n- **S3 Bucket Maintenance:** We will create and maintain two AWS S3 buckets: one for testnet and one for mainnet, both in the **eu-central-1 region**. Operations will include **300M PUT, COPY, POST, LIST requests** and **1 billion GET and SELECT requests** monthly paid by the requester. As NEAR\\\\u{2019}s ecosystem expands, our infrastructure can scale dynamically to handle increased data loads and traffic without compromising performance. separation of indexing from state tracking, exploration of cheaper storage alternatives\\\\n- **Milestone 6 (Month 9):** setting up a second vendor based on the new tech stack, verifications in place for data integrity vs the previous solution\\\\n- **Milestone 7 (Month 10):** enabling incentives over lava based on usage for the multi vendor set up\\\\n\\\\n![https://ipfs.near.social/ipfs/bafkreifh3n4b7dnhutedfahwnhddckvwycnbdqhchvxcc3ai5cb7x5rjce](https://ipfs.near.social/ipfs/bafkreifh3n4b7dnhutedfahwnhddckvwycnbdqhchvxcc3ai5cb7x5rjce)", "linked_proposals": [], "receiver_account": "8d51039cd656f1d9716894420b62555b68022797e7214adf4f630c77caf1cf66", "requested_sponsor": "infrastructure-committee.near", "proposal_body_version": "V1", "requested_sponsorship_usd_amount": "660000", "requested_sponsorship_paid_in_currency": "NEAR"}, "labels": []}

Our team, with extensive experience in blockchain RPC infrastructure, is committed to providing a high-performance, secure, and decentralized RPC service that aligns with NEAR\\\\\\'s vision and Web3 values. Additionally we are very keen on Near\\\\u{2019}s vision and the approach to sharding and have been active token holders long before this proposal.\\\\n\\\\n### Organization\\\\nBlockJoy is a venture-backed Delaware C-Corporation with its headquarters in Boston, MA. BlockJoy specializes in Node Operation and Management and is backed by Gradient Ventures (Google\\\\u{2019}s venture arm), Borderless Capital, Draper Dragon, Tribe Capital, Active Capital, and other crypto and infrastructure investors.\\\\n\\\\n**Primary Contact Information:**\\\\n  - Name: Eric Ullrich\\\\n  - Email: eric@blockjoy.com\\\\n\\\\n**Team Size and Location:**\\\\n  - Whole Team: 13\\\\n  - Engineering Team: 9\\\\n  - Location: Global distributed with US headquarters.\\\\n\\\\n **Team Background and Bios:**\\\\nOur team consists of experienced professionals with a strong background in devops, blockchain technology and RPC infrastructure management. Key team members include:\\\\n- Chris Bruce, CEO - 5x Technical Founder, formerly Head of Product Development and Board of Directors at Helium, https://www.linkedin.com/in/chrisabruce/\\\\n- Caleb Call, VP Infrastructure, formerly Head of Platform Engineering at Ripple, https://www.linkedin.com/in/calebcall/\\\\n- Matei Popa, Blockchain Reliability Engineer, previously Senior DevOps Engineer at CoW Protocol, https://www.linkedin.com/in/mateipopa/\\\\n- Cade Call, Blockchain Reliability Engineer, previously Lead DevOps Engineer at Medici Ventures, https://www.linkedin.com/in/cadecall/\\\\n\\\\n\\\\n### Professional Experience\\\\n- BlockJoy started as one of the most successful Validators as a Service platforms on Helium and at one point was operating over 50% of the Helium network. Our services offered the best cost-to-performance ratio and had the highest ROI out of all the other providers.\\\\n- We later ran Helium\\\\u{2019}s entire public API. Consisting of over 30 clustered Postgres servers with 40TB of data each and 20 application servers (scaling as high as 100 when needed). We migrated Helium off AWS and ran everything in house on bare metal hardware. We implemented our own custom caching configuration, multi-region load balancing, and rate limiting. At its peak, we were handling over 300M requests/day. Additionally, we ran nearly 20 private APIs for companies like Binance, Crypto.com, Seed, and Nova Labs.\\\\n- Today we use the same custom built infrastructure to run over 500 nodes with support for over 30 protocols and adding new protocols and nodes weekly. We are currently serving nearly 2B rpc requests per month.\\\\n\\\\n**Examples of Relevant Experience with Helium Blockchain Public RPC:**\\\\n- Operated Helium\\\\u{2019}s entire public API, in house on bare metal\\\\n- Operated the largest Validators as a Service for the Helium Network, 1600 validators\\\\n- Using our custom build infrastructure, we saved helium over $2M/year in operational costs\\\\n- Our Helium validators had the lowest cost and highest ROI out of the entire network\\\\n- Ran private Helium APIs for Binance, Crypto.com, Seed, and Nova Labs\\\\n\\\\n**Examples of Relevant Experience with NEAR Blockchain:**\\\\n- Integration of NEAR Blockchain to BlockVisor, enabling one-click deployment of high performance, unmetered RPC nodes to any server.  Features of Blockvisor include: one-click deployment, monitoring, alerting, logging on per node instance, efficient image upgrade and downgrade procedure, fast enrollment of new server to system, powerful management UX. All on bare metal servers resulting in lower costs and higher performance.\\\\n\\\\n### Main Appproach and Solution\\\\n- BlockJoy has developed a purpose-built suite of tools designed specifically for operating and managing Blockchain Nodes on bare metal servers (servers running without virtual machines, docker, or kubernetes) without the mismatched Web2 tooling. These tools enable BlockJoy to run nodes in a highly performant manner resulting in higher throughput and lower operating costs than is typically seen on virtual machine and container based systems. Based on our experience, we can typically operate at 20% or less the cost of running on the cloud. Furthermore, we typically remove 3-5ms from response times of container based virtualization.\\\\n- For execution of this grant, we will utilize BlockJoy\\\\u{2019}s purpose-built node orchestration technology to efficiently handle node deployment, version updates, monitoring and alerting of full nodes and archive nodes. \\\\n- We will leverage our partnerships with several of the leading bare metal datacenter providers around the world for our bare metal servers and use best in class hardware (Gen4 AMD EPYC CPUs, NVMe5 disks, and a 10Gb network.) We strongly believe this helps to build a more diverse and resilient network that all protocols should be striving for. As a case in point, Hetzner, without notice, decided to pull the plug on all Solana validators running within their data centers, resulting in around 30% of solana\\\\u{2019}s validators going offline and triggering a huge token price crash. \\\\n- We will implement a robust load balancer to ensure high availability throughput and low latency. This system will incorporate global load balancing to efficiently route traffic to the nearest RPC nodes. We will establish rate limiting based on criteria such as URI, request volume across multiple time windows, upstream host capabilities, number of connections to the upstream host, response time, and IP address. Additionally, our solution will include caching specific calls to provide quicker response times. We will also conduct automatic health checks on upstream nodes to swiftly identify and replace any unhealthy nodes from the network, ensuring continuous and reliable service.\\\\n- We will implement a monitoring and alerting system that includes the following components:\\\\n  - External Synthetic Checks: Conducted from eight geographic locations to ensure nodes are operational and responding with expected results. Alerts will be triggered for failures such as non-200 responses, long response times, or unexpected responses.\\\\n  - Ping Checks: Performed on every host system to verify simple up/down status, with alerts issued if a system goes down.\\\\n  - Full System Metrics: Monitored for prolonged high CPU load, high memory usage, and low disk space, with alerts for any prolonged issues.\\\\n  - System and Blockchain Logs Collection: Alerts will be generated for error events, out-of-memory events, and blockchain-specific events as appropriate.\\\\n  - Full Blockchain Metrics Collection: Monitored from the client side, with alerts for RPC errors and other protocol-specific metrics.\\\\n  - Load Balancer Monitoring: Includes external synthetic checks from eight geographic locations to ensure functionality, with alerts for failures such as non-200 responses or unexpected results.\\\\n  - External-Facing Status Page: We will implement a nice looking custom status page utilizing a tool such as Atlassian Statuspage.\\\\n- We will implement a comprehensive security plan that includes robust DDoS protection via Cloudflare with IP whitelisting and blocking capabilities. We maintain detailed logging and monitoring with 13-month retention allowing for year-over-year analysis and behavior trends, utilizing the LGTM stack (Loki, Grafana, Tempo, and Mimir). \\\\n- Disaster recovery will be addressed through our regular snapshot service.  We maintain nodes that are used to take regular snapshots, we then store multiple versions of those snapshots which allows us to quickly deploy new nodes.  This also allows us to scale very quickly as well if there are unexpected sustained surges in traffic.  In addition to maintaining snapshots, we\\\\u{2019}ve established strategic partnerships with Data Centers throughout the world maintaining strong relationships and ensuring we\\\\u{2019}re not reliant on any one hardware provider.\\\\n- BlockJoy\\\\\\'s SRE team will provide ad-hoc support on community forums, GitHub issues, and developer community channels such as Slack, Telegram, and Discord, with best-effort responses within 24-48 hours for generic services. We will assist in updating documentation for node operation on near.org.  Additionally, we will offer white-glove service support to facilitate the transition of high-priority overflow business, assisting in the migration of high-value users from public RPC to private NEAR RPC providers.\\\\n\\\\n**Why Choose This Project:**\\\\n- Our team offers proven expertise in high-performance RPC infrastructure, a strong understanding of NEAR protocol architecture, and a commitment to decentralization and open-source principles.\\\\nWe believe in the philosophy of the Near token project and our founder has been a Near token holder long before the last Crypto crash.\\\\n- Our team has extensive experience in building and maintaining high-performance public RPC infrastructure on decentralized networks of bare metal servers for tier one blockchain networks such as Helium and Ripple. Additionally, we have on staff software developers constantly improving our tooling so our nodes can perform their best.\\\\n- We have a strong understanding of NEAR protocol architecture and technical specifications.\\\\n- We have a proven track record of handling high transaction volumes and ensuring low latency in a cost efficient manner.\\\\n- Lastly, our software is designed to run and manage blockchain nodes on any infrastructure. By distributing nodes across multiple bare metal vendors (instead of centralizing it to our own hardware) and not utilizing traditional Cloud companies, we help to make the Near Network more diverse and more resilient. \\\\n### Goals / Milestones\\\\n**Transition Timeline:**\\\\n- Nov 1st: Initial knowledge transfer and transition planning. Support in transition of high value public endpoint users to dedicated RPC clusters through BlockJoy or other 3rd party RPC solutions.\\\\n- December 1st: Implementation of all dedicated Near RPC nodes and load balancer across 7 data centers globally.  Initial testing and monitoring implementation\\\\n- January 1st: Transition to BlockJoy load balancing and monitoring and alerting infrastructure.\\\\n- February 1st: Complete transition and operational handover.\\\\n\\\\n**Deliverables:**\\\\nAs part of our grant deliverables, we will establish a fully operational free-tier-only NEAR.org RPC service with the following features:\\\\n- Response Time latency \\\\u{2264} 200ms\\\\n- High Availability Throughput: See budget breakdown for details based on various scenarios.\\\\n- Service Level Agreement: Ensuring 99.99% uptime.\\\\n- External-Facing Status Page: To communicate system status and updates effectively.\\\\n- White-Glove Service Support: Assisting high-value RPC NEAR Foundation partners (dApps) in transitioning to private RPC solutions\\\\n\\\\n**Success Measurement:**\\\\n- Project success will be measured by achieving the following key performance indicators (KPIs):\\\\n- Uptime: Maintain a 99.99% monthly uptime.\\\\n- Performance: Providing extremely low response time latency averaging 200 ms or better.\\\\n- User Transition: Successfully transition high-value users to private RPC options through BlockJoy\\\\\\'s dedicated node clusters or other providers.\\\\n- Developer support: Successfully supporting and growth the near developers ecosystem through engagement on forums and through maintaining updated documentation.\\\\n### Budget\\\\n- **Budget Total:**\\\\n  - $26,088 per month, 6 month minimum commitment\\\\n- **Budget Breakdown:**\\\\n\\\\n![https://ipfs.near.social/ipfs/bafkreih5ravkgskospg45wo52zr2ofk4bw76f6g4vle7wlrrkum5k2g6ha](https://ipfs.near.social/ipfs/bafkreih5ravkgskospg45wo52zr2ofk4bw76f6g4vle7wlrrkum5k2g6ha)\\\\n\\\\n**Budget Narrative:**\\\\nOur proposed budget is based on Scenario 1, which assumes there will be a minimum of 50% reduction in total request volume to near.org RPCs due to the efforts to transition high usage accounts to private providers.  However if aggregate usage averages a 10x reduction or greater from current levels, we propose the scenario 2 budget.  A detailed unit-based analysis supporting the proposed budget is [available here.](https://docs.google.com/spreadsheets/d/1DM7GGguhDPMYfSDe2D7VEAnTlbY1ECwvmrSexc9FwXc/edit?gid=0#gid=0)\\\\n- Salaries: Contributing to engineering staff that will be responsible for deployment, testing, maintenance, incident response, and SRE efforts.\\\\n- Infrastructure Costs:  In Scenario 2 we anticipate supporting an average of 5k RPS, with capacity to burst up over 8k RPS.  To achieve this we anticipate running the following nodes: 10 mainnet-full, 4 mainnet-archive, 2 testnet-full, 2 testnet-archive. This alongside our caching technology will ensure excellent latency and reliability.\\\\n- Third-party Services Costs: This includes software fees of $1,600 for services such as Grafana and a hosted status page.\\\\n- Load Balancer Cost: Assuming average of 11B requests per month at $0.3 per 500k requests.\\\\n- This budget strategy ensures that Near.org RPC receives excellent service, while not overpaying for unused capacity for an extended period of time. \\\\n### Testimonials:**\\\\n> Since switching to BlockJoy, we are now able to run our API nodes outside legacy cloud providers, and we anticipate saving over 60% of our operating costs. This partnership has also saved our team hundreds of hours per month by no longer having to manage daily fires. The cost and time saved have already made a significant difference in our operations, and we\\\\u{2019}re excited to see how far this partnership takes Us. \\\\n-- Marc Nijdam, CTO, NOVA LABS\\\\n", "linked_proposals": [], "receiver_account": "blockjoyw3.near", "requested_sponsor": "infrastructure-committee.near", "proposal_body_version": "V1", "requested_sponsorship_usd_amount": "156528", "requested_sponsorship_paid_in_currency": "USDC"}, "labels": []}

Resulting in 320M calls per day.\\\\n\\\\n#### Reliability and Security\\\\n- Experienced in handling:\\\\n  - Traffic surges of 30,000 RPS\\\\n  - DDoS attacks (recently)\\\\n  - Provider outages\\\\n  - Testnet/mainnet issues\\\\n- Free NEAR Lake alternative at https://neardata.xyz\\\\n\\\\n#### Monitoring and Performance\\\\n- Internal monitoring and alert systems\\\\n- External status page https://status.fastnear.com\\\\n\\\\n## Body\\\\n\\\\n### (Background) NEARDATA by FASTNEAR\\\\n\\\\nFASTNEAR provides a simple and free alternative to the publicly available S3-based service NEAR Lake Framework called NEARDATA (https://neardata.xyz).\\\\n\\\\nFeatures:\\\\n- Data is grouped by blocks.\\\\n- Data is accessible through HTTPS for free.\\\\n- Each `ExecutionOutcome` for every Action Receipt contains originating transaction hash.\\\\n- Data is cached locally and by Cloudflare.\\\\n- Ability to read blocks from the browser.\\\\n- Ability to get recent optimistic blocks.\\\\n- Ability to download raw archived data. Useful for backfills.\\\\n\\\\nExample of the blocks timestamp to the wall time latency from NEARDATA:\\\\n![NEARDATA Latency](https://gist.github.com/user-attachments/assets/f0033340-0d66-4c92-be45-14e632bb9df8)\\\\n\\\\nFASTNEAR is already indexing and serving the following:\\\\n- NEAR Mainnet Final blocks\\\\n- NEAR Mainnet Optimistic blocks (with an average of 1- second wall to block-timestamp latency)\\\\n- NEAR Testnet Final blocks https://testnet.neardata.xyz\\\\n- NEAR Testnet Optimistic blocks\\\\n\\\\nWe provide data in the following formats:\\\\n- Full indexed blocks (including all data for all shards) in JSON file accessible throught HTTPS. Examples:\\\\n    - Latest finalized mainnet block: https://mainnet.neardata.xyz/v0/last_block/final\\\\n    - Latest optimistic mainnet block: https://mainnet.neardata.xyz/v0/last_block/optimistic\\\\n    - Latest finalized testnet block: https://testnet.neardata.xyz/v0/last_block/final\\\\n    - Block `123456789` on mainnet: https://mainnet.neardata.xyz/v0/block/123456789\\\\n    - Block `123456789` on testnet: https://testnet.neardata.xyz/v0/block/123456789\\\\n- Pending finalized blocks. When you request a block by height that is close to the head, but is not produced yet, the server will hold the connection until the block becomes available. Making it easy to implement indexers.\\\\n- Archival data by 10 block archives, allows to quickly backfill data. Over the past two and a half years, the focus has been on building and refining a robust data pipeline designed to deliver maximum speed, high availability, fault tolerance, and efficient global data access.\\\\n\\\\nTo support these capabilities, the team includes engineers with experience in the relevant parts of the nearcore codebase, which enables the maintenance and customization of an in-house version of the NEAR Indexer using the NEAR Indexer Framework. This specialized knowledge has been instrumental in operating instances of nearcores and NEAR Indexers, ensuring that Aurora RPC services consistently achieve high availability and performance.\\\\n\\\\nThe entire infrastructure is continuously monitored and backed-up to maintain optimal performance and reliability across various regions worldwide, aligning with the company\\\\\\'s commitment to delivering resilient and responsive blockchain services.\\\\n\\\\n## Body\\\\n\\\\nThe proposed solution involves adopting the current setup for NEAR Lake from the Pagoda team, with a focus on ensuring reliability and high availability, eliminating potential vulnerabilities, and establishing comprehensive monitoring. The approach includes deploying new or additional indexer instances if necessary to meet failover/latency demands.\\\\n\\\\nAdditionally, there is a plan to potentially integrate the process of writing to NEAR Lake into the existing infrastructure pipeline in the future, aiming to reduce operational costs by reusing data from the indexers for both internal needs of Aurora infrastructure and the needs of NEAR Lake.\\\\n\\\\n## Goals / Milestones\\\\n\\\\n1. (Optional/Later): integrate lake indexer with existing Aurora infrastructure\\\\n\\\\n## Metrics\\\\n\\\\nKey things that have to be tracked:\\\\n- Per-indexer metrics - have to be exported from indexer instances:\\\\n\\\\t- Liveness status\\\\n\\\\t- Sync/unsync status\\\\n\\\\t- Current progression\\\\n\\\\t- Errors\\\\n- Bucket progression metrics - shall be measured by reading from S3 using lake client library (indexer framework):\\\\n\\\\t- Current progression\\\\n\\\\t- Fetching/parsing errors\\\\n\\\\t- Lag from the final block (shall be compared against final block querying from RPC)\\\\n- Total uptime is calculated as: total time when lag was less than 5 blocks\\\\n\\\\nSuccess condition: uptime during the evaluation period is at least 99.9%\\\\n\\\\n## Budget\\\\n\\\\nThe budget might be re-evaluated in future due to:\\\\n\\\\t- Growth of monthly-generated NEAR data\\\\n\\\\t- Pipeline optimizations applied by Aurora Labs team\\\\n\\\\n### Budget total\\\\n\\\\n$35,000 USD per quarter\\\\n\\\\n### Budget Breakdown\\\\n\\\\nS3 costs breakdown:\\\\n- Assuming that:\\\\n  - Writes cost per year per network per instance = 183960000 / 1000 * 0.0054 USD = 993 USD\\\\n  - Total writes cost per year = 1987 USD * 2 networks * 3 replicas = 5958 USD\\\\n- Read cost:\\\\n  - LIST requests per year per network per instance = 183960000 objects / 1000 = 183960 requests\\\\n  - 7 machines in total\\\\n- Total cost per year: 7 machines * 1551 USD ~= $11k USD\\\\n\\\\nOperational overhead and safety margin:\\\\n- $8k / month ~= $96k / year\\\\n\\\\nTotal cost for the first year = $30k + $11k + $96k = ~$137k\\\\n\\\\nWe propose to structure the contract with quarterly payments: $35k/quarter\\\\n", "linked_proposals": [], "receiver_account": "aurorasupport.near", "requested_sponsor": "infrastructure-committee.near", "proposal_body_version": "V1", "requested_sponsorship_usd_amount": "35000", "requested_sponsorship_paid_in_currency": "USDC"}, "labels": []}
